DOC.HEAD: Romania's Ceausescu Visits Tehran Amid Turmoil at Home
With AM-Romania, Bjt
LaserPhoto TEH2
DOC.TEXT: Romanian President Nicolae Ceausescu and his Iranian counterpart Hashemi Rafsanjani began talks in Tehran on Monday to cement economic ties amid political turbulence in Romania stirred by Eastern Europe's reformist wave. The Islamic Republic News Agency said the two met shortly after Ceausescu arrived on a three-day official visit. It said further meetings were planned to bolster political and economic links. Ceausescu told Rafsanjani, ``I am pleased to be the first president to visit Iran after your election,'' Tehran radio reported. Rafsanjani, elected president in July, assured Ceausescu ``there are many fields of cooperation in boosting bilateral trade,'' it added. IRNA and the radio were both monitored in Nicosia. Referring to Ceausescu's inflexibility while the political change surged through Eastern Europe, IRNA praised Romania as ``the sole East European country rigidly adhering to its past government.'' Ceausescu, elected Romanian Communist Party chief in 1965, is the longest-serving leader in the Soviet bloc. He has stamped out almost all dissent in Romania. His crash industrialization program and his frantic efforts to repay all of Romania's $11 billion debt have led to perennial shortages of consumer goods and rationing of basic foodstuffs. On Monday, Romania sealed its border with Yugoslavia to all but official traffic after an anti-government demonstration turned violent in Timisoara, west Romania. The Iranian agency said others attending Monday's talks in Tehran were Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, Vice President Masoud Roghani Zanjani and Heavy Industries Minister Hadi Nejad-Husseinian of Iran, and Deputy Prime Minister Ion Radu, Foreign Minister Ion Stoian and presidential adviser Constantion Mitea of Romania. Ceausescu's politically powerful wife Elena stayed behind in Romania, although she usually accompanies her husband on trips abroad. Ceausescu will complete agreements reached by the Tehran-Bucharest commission that met in Iran last week. ``The Iran-Romania summit is an expression of the positive course of relations between our countries and people,' Ceausescu was quoted as telling the English-language daily, the Tehran Times. Contacts so far were having good results ``especially in economic and technical-scientific cooperation,'' he said in excerpts quoted by IRNA. The interview apparently was conducted earlier in Bucharest. Romania is a major trading partner with Iran. The agreements Ceausescu is expected to conclude will boost their volume of trade from about $1.8 billion this year to $3 billion, IRNA said. Tehran radio reported Sunday that Iran will export about 1 million barrels of oil and 1 billion cubic meters of natural gas a year to Romania. The agreement was concluded Sunday at a meeting between Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh and Radu. Iran earlier this year announced plans to export 5 million metric tons of crude oil to Romania in return for tractors, oil drilling equipment and military equipment, including tanks. IRNA said that under Sunday's agreement, Romania will supply equipment for constructing Tehran's subway system. Romanian experts are also working with the Iranians on a major irrigation dam project at Raveh, 20 miles south of Tehran. Budapest radio, quoting unidentified witnesses, said security forces on Monday sealed off Timisoara, which has a population of 350,000 and is the largest city in the ethnically mixed region of Transylvania. Reports of deaths there have surfaced. Romanian emigres said thousands of demonstrators battled security forces over the weekend after ransacking a library and burning books by Ceausescu.
